article.description: Romain Sato scored a career-high 35 points, and Anthony Myles added 17 points and 12 rebounds, leading No. 14 Xavier to its 10th straight victory, 93-71 over La Salle on Wednesday night.
article.headline: Sato scores 35 points in victory against La Salle
article.linkText: Sato's career night powers Xavier to 10th straight win
article.story: PHILADELPHIA -- Romain Sato's early season shooting slump is well behind him. The junior guard scored a career-high 35 points, and Anthony Myles added 17 points and 12 rebounds, leading No. 14 Xavier to its 10th straight victory, 93-71 over La Salle on Wednesday night. Lionel Chalmers had 13 points and David West added 12 for the Musketeers (19-4, 10-1 Atlantic 10). "Even when I wasn't making my shots, my teammates gave me the ball,'' Sato said. "They kept telling me I'm a good shooter.'' Sato is Xavier's second-leading scorer at 18.2 points per game. He's averaging 21.1 points in his last 15 games after a six-game stretch in which he averaged 10.2. Gary Neal scored a career-high 37 points for La Salle (10-12, 4-7), which has lost two straight and seven of 10. Xavier, which was ranked 10th in the preseason poll, finally is living up to early expectations. The Musketeers have won 10 of their last 11 by at least 12 points, including a 33-point victory over La Salle last month. "As poorly as we did things tonight, it was good to get a win,'' Xavier coach Thad Matta said. La Salle led briefly in the opening minutes. A 3-pointer by Neal put the Explorers ahead 8-6, before Xavier went on a 13-2 run. The Musketeers never trailed after Chalmers hit a 3-pointer that made it 9-8. Sato, coming off a 34-point performance in a 23-point victory over Rhode Island last Saturday, was 10-for-17 from the field and made all 10 of his free throws. He missed his first three 3s, but finished 5-for-11 from beyond the arc. "Coach told me to just keep shooting,'' Sato said. At one point in the second half, Sato scored 11 straight points for Xavier, including three 3-pointers. His third 3 capped a 13-2 run, and gave the Musketeers a 61-36 lead, their biggest to that point. Chalmers, starting his second game since breaking his foot on Dec. 31, was 3-for-5 from beyond the arc. West, a preseason All-America, finished with six rebounds, ending his streak of 10 consecutive games with double figures in points and rebounds. He has 17 double-doubles, the most in Division I entering the night. "I have total respect for their program,'' La Salle coach Billy Hahn said. "You have to pick your poison against them. They totally dominated us.'' Neal scored 13 straight points for La Salle in the second half, including three consecutive 3-pointers. His third 3 got the Explorers within 79-60, but after a hook shot by Dzaflo Larkai, Xavier scored five in a row to put the game away. La Salle was without Steven Smith, its second-leading scorer at 14.5 points per game. The freshman forward is out four-to-six weeks after injuring his left foot on Feb. 8. Xavier shot 51.6 percent (16-for-31), made all 13 of its free throws in the first half, and led 47-32 at halftime. "We knew they were wounded, but looking to have a big game,'' West said. "We had to make sure to jump on them early.''
